title: St Michael's Church, North Rode
text:
St Michael's Church is in Church Lane, <a href="North%20Rode">North Rode</a>, <a href="Cheshire">Cheshire</a>, England. It is an active <a href="Anglican">Anglican</a> <a href="parish%20church">parish church</a> in the deanery of Macclesfield, the archdeaconry of Macclesfield, and the <a href="diocese%20of%20Chester">diocese of Chester</a>. Its <a href="benefice%23Church%20of%20England">benefice</a> is combined with those of <a href="Church%20of%20St%20Mary%20the%20Virgin%2C%20Bosley">St Mary the Virgin, Bosley</a>, <a href="St%20Saviour%27s%20Church%2C%20Wildboarclough">St Saviour, Wildboarclough</a>, and <a href="St%20Michael%27s%20Church%2C%20Wincle">St Michael, Wincle</a>. The church is recorded in the <a href="National%20Heritage%20List%20for%20England">National Heritage List for England</a> as a designated Grade II <a href="Listed%20building%23England%20and%20Wales">listed building</a>. The authors of the "<a href="Pevsner%20Architectural%20Guides">Buildings of England</a>" series describe it as "a charming estate church".
History.
St Michael's was built in 1845–46, and designed by <a href="Charles%20Trubshaw">Charles</a> and <a href="James%20Trubshaw">James Trubshaw</a>.
Architecture.
Exterior.
The church is constructed in <a href="rubble">rubble</a> stone with <a href="ashlar">ashlar</a> dressings, and has a tiled roof. Its plan consists of a four-<a href="bay%20%28architecture%29">bay</a> <a href="nave">nave</a>, a south porch, a two-bay <a href="chancel">chancel</a> with a <a href="vestry">vestry</a> to the northeast, and a west tower. The tower has angle <a href="buttress">buttress</a>es and a plain <a href="parapet">parapet</a>. In the angle between the tower and the nave on the north side is a stair <a href="Turret%20%28architecture%29">turret</a> which rises above the height of the tower, and contains round-headed <a href="casement%20window">casement window</a>s. On the west side of the tower is a doorway with a semicircular head in a loosely <a href="Romanesque%20architecture">Romanesque</a> style, which is decorated with spaced chevron motifs. Above the door is a two-light window in loosely <a href="English%20Gothic%20architecture%23Early%20English%20Gothic">Early English</a> style, with a circular clock face above that. On each side of the top stage are three <a href="lancet%20window">lancet</a> bell openings. The south porch has a loosely Romanesque doorway, above which is a <a href="niche%20%28architecture%29">niche</a> containing a statue of <a href="Michael%20%28archangel%29">Saint Michael</a>. The windows along the sides of the church are in Early English style.
Interior.
Inside the church, the nave has a <a href="hammerbeam%20roof">hammerbeam roof</a>. Both the nave and the chancel are floored with <a href="encaustic%20tile">encaustic tile</a>s. In the church are four brass corona <a href="chandelier">chandelier</a>s. The <a href="baptismal%20font">font</a> is decorated with encaustic tiles. In the church are memorials to the Daintry and Tootal Broadhurst families. The stained glass is described as being "delightfully bad".
